RISK AND PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN 2009

1  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code A?25531 through A?25543.3, this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal/ARP) Risk Management Plan under the Program Level 3 Designation.

The scope of this RMP is based on guidance from the City of Oxnard Fire Department Certified Unified Program Agency (Oxnard Fire/CUPA- the Agency with local authority for the RMP and Cal/ARP Programs),  to ensure that contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  The facility uses anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) in a closed-loop refrigeration process (20,000 lbs. maximum intended inventory) for temperature control of fresh onions.  Under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia is used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system (1200 lbs. maximum).  The SCR is used to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas-fired turbine. This system is currently used as backup in case of power failure.  The ammonia refrigeration system and SCR processes trigger the RMP requirements, both Federal and Cal/ARP. These processes were determined to be covered by Prevention Program III requirements.

At the time of this writing, the SCR Process was not being used; and the ammonia inventory in the SCRA?s Receiver was negligible.  The facility however considers power backup essential

to its business operations; this second Process will be kept on standby.  Ammonia may be added to the SCR Ammonia Receiver at any time facility management deems the need for backup power is necessary or imminent.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Gill's Onions policy is to protect its employees, environment, property, and the general public from harm that may occur as a result of its operations. To achieve this end, Gill's Onions strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  With regard to the Ammonia Refrigeration and SCR Systems, the Accidental Release Prevention policy is to maintain compliance with the Risk and Process Safety Management Prevention Program elements.  The RMP/PSM programs are specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases; and to deal safely with emergencies if they do happen.

Gills Onions has adopted a A?Non-responding facilityA? policy; Emergency Response pre-planning is coordinated with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA; Facility Management and the Refrigeration Plant Operator.  The Refrigeration Plant Operator is a licensed Contractor C-38 Classification with 30+ years experience and national recognition from the Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).  Gills Onions has filed appropriate reports with the CUPA; measures have been taken to ensure the facility is included in the Community Emergency Plan.  The CUPA makes regular visits to the facility in accordance with California environmental regulations, which helps keep engine companies refreshed on Plant operations and layout.  The Gills Onions Emergency response policies are implemented to comply with the overall company policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and minimizing risk to the public. Safety is the top priority.  Another priority is protection of the environment. Only after life, safety, and environmental concern

s are addressed will the focus shift to the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery.

1.2  General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Oxnard is located on the southern margin of the Oxnard Plain, approximately 5 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 50 miles west of Los Angeles, California. The elevation of the facility is approximately 35 feet above sea level. The nearest earthquake faults are the Pitas Point-Ventura Fault, approximately 8 miles to the northwest and the Anacapa (Dume) Fault, approximately 16 miles to the southwest located in the Pacific Ocean. The Anacapa (Dume) Fault produced a 5.9 magnitude earthquake in 1973.

The facility is located in a limited industrial (M-2) zone, covers approximately 14 acres and is bounded on the north by Mountain View Avenue, on the east by Pacific Avenue and on the south by Wooley Road. The Ventura County Railway Spur runs along the western property line which is shared with other light industrial facilities to the west. The nearest major highway is State Route 1, the Pacific Coast Highway, approximately 0.5-miles to the west.

The nearest residential area, East Ash Street, is approximately 0.5-miles to the southwest. The next nearest residential area, La Puerta Street in La Colonia neighborhood, is approximately 0.65 miles to the northeast. The Oxnard Community Center Complex is approximately 1.25-miles to the west and the Center Point Mall is approximately 1.1 miles to the southwest. These are considered public receptors under the RMP regulation. The nearest designated environmental receptor is a Natural Preserve approximately 6 miles northwest of the facility. The Natural Preserve is located just north of McGrath State Beach on the Santa Clara River outlet to the Pacific Ocean.

The facility is designed to process and store onions. Processing includes washing, peeling, dicing, and packaging onions. The cold storage room, shipping dock, and receiving

ffic around ammonia equipment (refrigeration and SCR) is minimized with facility design; barriers, and signs.
A?    The facility is protected from fire by an independent fire suppression system. 
A?    Sensitive areas have signage; and are fenced and monitored with CCTVA?s
A?    Staff maintains housekeeping of the facility according to Food Safety Protocols on a day-to-day basis.
A?    The Refrigeration Plant Operator makes rounds on a regular basis and is on call.  
A?    The Plant has an established formal Inspection and Maintenance program.  
A?    A formal Injury and Illness Prevention & Training Program (IIPP) is established.  Personnel are trained according to their position and level of responsibility. 
A?    Employees are trained in hazard communication (Awareness level).
A?    Ammonia detectors
A?    Alarms: horns and beacon lights
A?    Emergency control panel linked to independent alarm systems controller to notify local emergency crews (i.e., fire department, police, etc.)
A?    Both the Refrigeration and SCR Systems are equipped with Fire Dept. Emergency Control Boxes
A?    Emergency shut-down switches
A?    Automatic cut-outs on refrigeration equipment
A?    Relief valves on both processes piped to header leading to ammonia A? water (20,000 Ga.) diffuser tank
A?    pH monitors

Major changes since the last PHA include:

Replacement of primary ammonia pumps with seal-less type, installation of CCTVA?s and water shower over ammonia pumps, installation of two new Compressors, revision of SOPA?s and associated training of personnel.  Other equipment upgrades and/or maintenance are documented in Mechanical Integrity Maintenance Records.
